Thank you. President, let me first of all greet the President of the DTP party, Mr. Ahmet Turk, who is here with us in the Tribunal of Honor and who follows the debate.

Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the Left in Europe have since then supported the process of Turkey's accession to the European Union, while at the same time supporting the process of reforms in that country.

I believe, however, that in the last two years and especially in the last few months, Erdogan has shown another side, that of a leader committed to the worst part of the Turkish army, who simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead. The prisons are filled with Kurds. Erdogan himself, who is closing any prospect of adhesion of Turkey,
It is his and only his responsibility what is happening in the Euro-Turkish relations and the growing perplexity of the European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan. Either you are looking for a negotiated political solution to the Kurdish issue, a priority that passes, whether clearly, through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to ask for the suspension of negotiations on adhesion to the European Union.

The road of the union's accession to Turkey is going through Diarkovi and the DTP, otherwise it will be us, those who have supported the process of accession, who will ask for a pause of reflection that may be definitive.

Presidente, Mr. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, it is not my intention, nor that of my group, which has supported and wanted this debate, to transfer to the European level the attributes of internal Italian politics.

The question of freedom of information concerns all of us, concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at the community level, in order to counter political and economic conditions and to guarantee a real pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, consists precisely in the existence of a dangerous gap between media, political and economic powers.

This is precisely why we are asking for a European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italianity, serves to protect the pluralism of information, avoiding concentrations and conflict of interest.

For this reason, today we ask the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has asked in the past, to provide the European Union with common norms to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.

Thank you, Mr. President. The proposal on the rights of passengers traveling by bus is aimed at improving and protecting passengers, particularly disabled or those with low mobility.
It is the first regulation on the rights of passengers via bus and should guarantee passengers, as it happens in the railway and air sector.
The position in the second reading is aimed at establishing a series of rights for passengers who decide to travel by bus,

I agree with the line of the reporter Cancian, which I thank for the excellent work done, and I believe that the scope of application of the regulation must be modified excluding the regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and necessary to guarantee the rights of passengers in case of accidents, cancellations or delays at departure, as was already decided in the first reading by the Parliament.

The information on passenger rights is equally important. It would be useful, in fact, to provide passengers with information on coincidences with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services through buses and those through railways.

As for disabled people with reduced mobility, maximum protection is necessary. I would propose a 24-hour term in place of 48, in order to require assistance, as well as greater guarantees for resuscitation and replacement of instruments that guarantee mobility of people with disabilities in the event of loss or damage.
Moreover, taking into account the need for low mobility passengers, it should be eliminated any architectural barriers and improve existing infrastructures to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, to promote intermodality, but above all to improve the travel conditions of passengers.

but the Cooperation and Development Regulation also contains the rules for the European Union's development policy.
These standards provide that when the Commission must grant financing, it must follow the procedures of the Committee of the Law.

This means that the Parliament has the right to examine this proposal of financing and, in the event that the Commission overcomes its competences, the Parliament can then adopt resolutions in order to ask the Commission to change the decisions in question.

From 2006 until today, the Parliament has only considered that in at least 12 cases the Commission has exceeded its executive competences, but only in three of these cases the Commission has in fact modified or withdrawn its decision proposal.
After the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Development Commission proposed to apply the procedure of the Delegated Acts provided by Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty,
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic decisions of financing that the European Commission must adopt, the Parliament would have a more relevant role.
In fact, according to the Lisbon Treaty, in some well-defined cases, the Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions. But what could these decisions be?
In our view, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide assistance for development

is a choice that is up to the legislator. So which sectors should then give priority to financing? Education? Health? Environmental protection? The ability of the good government? The development of small businesses?

These are the choices and matters in which the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has ever had in the past.

Mr President, honorable colleagues, Mr Council representative and Mrs Commissioner, first of all I would like to greet you positively, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved last June 6.
Corruption is a phenomenon of transnational importance and measures to combat it are necessary in European dimension.
The vast majority of our European citizens, according to the Eurobarometer estimates, believe that Europe should do more.
How to give them a twist?

In many Member States, the political will to counter corruption has been lacking. It is enough to think that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention on Corruption.

If we think about the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, on citizens' rights and on trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national measures of contrast adopted by Member States so far are insufficient to contain a phenomenon of expansion.

It is the European Union that must give a strong and unitary response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis that is weighing on the lives of people, on the maintenance of welfare systems and welfare, on the capacity of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes every year the loss of 120 billion euros, equal to 1% of the GDP of the European Union and daily subtracts the resources of the Union and the Member States
that could be used to provide basic services, such as education, childcare, employment, transport, in short, to extract clean resources to support people.

It is therefore necessary to have more courage and more firmness, both by monitoring the action of the anti-corruption measures, and by intensifying and unmasking the measures of contrast to corruption at the level of the Union.

In particular, we cannot talk about the fight against corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for the definition of the crime of corruption, which is not mentioned in the newly approved package.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters to measure the breadth of the phenomenon in Member States, essential to predispose an effective response.
We are in favour of, for example, relaunching the network of contact points of the ELE against corruption as proposed by the resolution that we will vote tomorrow.
is not from yesterday, it has already existed for some years.

We have always done appropriate analysis of the situation
the right approach has been chosen

President Barroso is facing a problem, the speed of the markets and the slowness of politics. Is this the only problem?

Of course, if we think that we are still at the implementation of the 21st of July, this should at least suggest that we prepare and better organize the vertices and their conclusions. But politics will be slower and slower than markets.
Then the point is to look further, to shift the focus on the fight against unemployment and development,
This is the field that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on growth and development indicators.

The Commission should go beyond its weakness, say that the priority is the fight against unemployment and the creation of jobs, redistribution of wealth and the strategy of public investments, changing also the rules of the new European Stability Act.
Mr President, I believe that the challenge of the next years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains the primacy of the former
a global tourist destination and at the same time be able to enhance both in terms of environmental protection and competitive capacity all its territorial heritage.

It is a challenging and not easy challenge, also in light not only of the opportunities but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, of other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as the Commissioner Tajani recalled, it becomes fundamental, as also in the opinion of the Commission that we have approved in the Regional Development Commission,
to keep together a strong general strategy of the entire European Union on tourism with a valorization of the role of the regions and territories.
In this sense, it is essential to have a full involvement, from the beginning, in respect of the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local entities.
Furthermore, I believe that it is necessary to encourage the development of integrated tourist networks and projects, starting from the creation of partnerships for the exchange of good prices,
I think it is also right to propose to identify a European brand that is able to define a high quality of the tourist product.
Obviously, the Commission will have to better define the priorities, especially from the financial point of view, to ensure that this European primacy is maintained in the future.

Thank you, President. European schools have been created with the aim of guaranteeing access to education in their mother tongue to the children of agents of European institutions called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of the country of origin.

and over the years, considering the positivity of this form of teaching, 14 European schools have been created within the various Member States.

And investing, we know that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans. Thank you President.

Greetings to the Commission. I must really thank all the people who have contributed in these weeks, in these months, to the production of this document that we are voting in the House today.
We have worked very well and a really constructive debate has developed.
The resolution proposal that we are voting for today, therefore, is the result of a really common work and is the result of the contribution of all political forces and of the entire Parliament.

I think a very strong common sensitivity has developed with respect to this topic, also because, we must remember, we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in disasters.
The numbers, if we look at them in their cruelty, are very eloquent. The number of catastrophes in the world has doubled. If we think that in 1975
78 catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we have almost 400 calamity events a year.

In the last 20 years, unfortunately, the victims of these catastrophes have been 90,000 and more than 29 million individuals have been hit by the catastrophes, while the economic losses amount to 211 billion euros.
It is evident that we are faced with such phenomena that require a stronger, more effective response and a really strong commitment from us.
We all have in our eyes the images of the Haiti earthquake, the floods in Pakistan, what happened in Japan,
Europe itself sees on its territory every year sudden floods, fires, we remember the cloud of ash followed by the eruption of the Icelandic volcano,
There is no need to go further to state how important the work that is being done here in Parliament is, following two principles
fundamental, which are our polar stars, the principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause of the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
we are moving on these lines.

President, we are experiencing a decisive step for the future of the euro and with it of all European construction.
Having this awareness would mean leaving a myopic logic that subordinates everything to an ideological will to be strict in the balance of accounts.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order, we all want to reduce the indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without an intelligent investment policy capable of giving the economy a breath of fresh air, there will be no chance of growth.
The only clear result in this setting is that the heaviest prices, as always, will be paid by the weaker prices.
For this reason, together with the Socialists and the Democrats, we voted against this report.
In fact, we are moving in a single direction, which is that of a rigorous and unimproved approach, a direction that has been revealed wrong until now.
I really appreciated the work done by the colleague Ferrera with this report.
In fact, on the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only on this, my group and I expressed a positive vote.

We did this because a clause was introduced, among other things, to protect social rights from collective bargaining and, furthermore, there is a strengthening of the role of the Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

Therefore, while not being able to change the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report will certainly be taken one step forward to have, among other things, a surveillance system that takes into account the fundamental rights.

And so, in this context, I remain firm that a vision, in our opinion, based only on a policy of austerity does not produce positive results, this relationship certainly constitutes a positive note in the counter-trend.

Ladies and gentlemen, Finland and the Netherlands have put themselves in the shoes of the Council for a very simple reason. Bulgaria and Romania are not able today to guarantee effective border control and are under the influence of a dilapidated corruption involving the political class and organized crime.
The populist movements are not the parties to think about it, but the Europol in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria entered the Raschenghe, the police and security agencies would expect that the Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become the easy target of Turkish and Eastern European crime and Bulgaria and Romania would become the crucivias of human trafficking and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some Member States have a lot of resources on the real capacity of Bulgaria and Romania to guarantee effective border control against organized crime and corruption. And it is therefore absolutely natural that they oppose their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means opening the way to transnational crime and opening a boat on the European borders, right where there is a very strong immigration pressure from Turkey.
There are many reasons to oppose them and Europe cannot ignore them.
I therefore ask to know what are the intentions of the Commission and the Council regarding this delicate matter, which in my opinion has been dealt with so far
and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would bring to the hands of competent bodies in matters of security and international criminalization.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should send back the entry of these two countries to Schengen and say OK only when there will be reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not be reduced to the safety of European citizens.

Thank you, President. The current global economic crisis, even more serious than the one of 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Commercial disparities among countries, financial markets lacking in common rules, instability of banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, to which I express my support, underlines the urgency of the new rules and the global economic coordination.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, a more responsible monetary policy and more severe supervision policies. The decision-making bodies and international economic organizations must be the main actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe needs a transparent blockade to reduce the exasperated stability even by globalization, guaranteeing reforms of broad-spectrum, in turn promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment and this resolution emphasizes to all countries.

Thank you, President. I expressed a favorable vote to the colleague's report, Mr. Matera, which analyzes the situation of single mothers, which today represent, as already said, more than 5% of the population of the European Union.

health care, flexible work, which allows to reconcile private and professional life, priority access to affordable accommodation and special unemployment benefits.

Thank you, thank you President. The phosphates present in detergents for household washing machines end up in water systems, in rivers, in torrents and in European lakes.

Phosphorus determines an acceleration of the reproduction of various forms of life. As a result, algae and other fast-growing vegetal species proliferate in an excessive amount when an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment is detected.
This excessive growth of algae removes oxygen from other living organisms. It can also produce toxins, destroying plant-based species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I expressed my vote in favour of the text I voted for today because to purify the European water heritage it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that is poured into the waters of our continent.

Mr President, the European Union has produced a huge amount of laws and regulations to build European law and created the European area, called the Stockholms Plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument and the use that citizens make of it, which is numerically and percentually very low.
On the other hand, national judges and national lawyers of the individual states have grown within the rights of their own country and have a prevailing formation in this sector.
while we believe that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mentality and who is intrigued by the knowledge of European law.

Therefore, before talking about training, we must talk about a great communication to citizens and law enforcement officers, so that they become the bearers of this great novelty and increase the ability to want to use the advantages of this law.

But above all, it is a movement from the bottom that must be created in the training in service. You cannot do a lesson like a schoolboy in the judicial training of adult and highly professional people.

We need to stimulate curiosity in dealing with our own cases, to connect with other colleagues and to find solutions, since today common law and civil law converge, they are no longer as distant as they were a long time ago within the legal culture.
This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am happy that the European Commission is convinced of these aspects, we ask for a trend reversal, bottom-up, more legal studies than judicial training.
There is a very interesting example in the Netherlands called Eurinfra. It is a network of officials in every court who radiate this knowledge and urge the magistrates to do so.
This is the essence of our project and we hope it will have support from the Commission.

Thank you, President. First of all, I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the work that colleague Giegel has done with this initiative. I also remember that with him and with others we share an active presence in the social economy intergroup of this Parliament.

As you know, my political group believes that the social model is one of the main characteristics of the European integration project. So it is not just one of the many policies, but a policy that characterizes our project.

And in these times, with the attacks also linked to the needs of cutting public spending, etc., we still defend this conviction, this priority. We know that it can be an updated, modified social model, but we also believe that it must be maintained, defended and rebutted as a priority.

So I think that in this same vision we must also value the economic subjects that make business, that make the production of goods and services such as cooperatives and that have a very particular role in the so-called European social economy.

They argue that we can produce, we can do good things, we can be efficient even if we don't have the profit as our goal, but we have the occupation, the welfare, the work and the contribution to the life of the local community.

That's why it's important, I conclude, President, that Europe makes available the useful tools for an active policy and make a good statute, not the one that exists now, unreachable, but a good one for cooperatives, can be a way to help this sector so important.
Thank you, Mr. President. The role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fairer economic dimension.

And in this moment, where we are going through one of the most serious economic and social crises since the post-war period, the function of cooperative societies becomes crucial. It is evident that where
if a robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy was achieved, an increase in employment, a more qualified job, a redistribution of wealth produced more balanced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a Statute for Cooperative Societies, but now more than ever it is necessary that there be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new momentum to the creation of a European common framework in the field of cooperation and this must happen by helping and not creating bureaucratic obstacles.
That is why I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to resolve the problems mentioned.

The survival of millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the additional assistance offered by the European Fund for Agribusiness. The collected data shows that most of the beneficiaries of the fund cannot find a new job, while the most fortunate are reintegrated into the labour market with contracts set at a time of only six months.
In many cases they are unemployed and give up this fund because they doubt their usefulness.
The FEG is not a solution and does not cover the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and with too much lightness by the Commission.

To combat the plague of structural unemployment, Europe must put a stop to its excessive opening to the markets of developing countries, whose real competition constitutes the first cause of the failures of our companies.
Until Europe stops promoting economic self-loathing, defending a miopic position towards global trade flows, our companies will continue to fail.
The Fund can only be a temporary support, but it is not thanks to training courses that our unemployed will find serenity and safety.
